Sure, here are a few examples:

1. In the TV series "This is Us," the use of flashbacks allows the audience to see the characters at different points in their lives, which helps to deepen the emotional connection between the audience and the characters. For example, when we see the Pearson family in the present day struggling with the loss of their father, we also get to see flashbacks of the family when the children were young and their father was still alive, which helps us understand their grief and loss on a deeper level.

2. In the film "Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind," the use of alternate storylines and flashbacks helps to create a complex emotional landscape for the characters. By showing us memories of the relationship between Joel and Clementine out of order and with different perspectives, we are able to see the highs and lows of their relationship and the reasons why they fell in love and ultimately decided to erase each other from their memories.

3. In the book "The Time Traveler's Wife," the use of alternate storylines creates a sense of emotional tension for the characters and the audience. The protagonist, Henry, is a time traveler who is often out of sync with his own life, and the author uses flashbacks and alternate timelines to show how his actions and choices impact the people around him. This creates a sense of emotional urgency for the audience, as we want to see how these choices will ultimately affect the characters' relationships and futures.
